Question_1.Context: The study investigated the friction and temperature behavior of surface coatings in rolling-sliding contacts for dry lubricated gears. The experimental setup included case-hardened steel 16MnCr5E (AISI5115) as substrate material together with two different coatings: a-C:H:Zr DLC coating (ZrCg) and a MoS2-bonded coating (MoS2-BoC).
Question_1.Question: What material was considered as the substrate material in the experimental setup?
Question_1.Source: Both test disks were made of case-hardened steel 16MnCr5E (AISI5115) with a surface hardness of 60 ± 2 HRC and a case hardening depth of CHD550HV1 = 0.9 ± 0.2 mm.

Question_2.Context: The study focused on investigating the friction and temperature behavior of surface coatings in rolling-sliding contacts for dry lubricated gears. The experimental setup included case-hardened steel 16MnCr5E (AISI5115) as substrate material together with two different coatings: a-C:H:Zr DLC coating (ZrCg) and a MoS2-bonded coating (MoS2-BoC).
Question_2.Question: Which coating was based on polyimide as a binder?
Question_2.Source: For contact temperature measurements, a MoS2-BoC was used that consists of 70 wt.% polyimide as binder and 30 wt.% of MoS2.

Question_3.Context: The study investigated the friction and temperature behavior of surface coatings in rolling-sliding contacts for dry lubricated gears. Question_3.Question: What was the purpose of using thin-film sensors in the study?
Question_3.Source: Besides contact temperature measurements were performed at constant sum velocity v∑ = 2 m/s, but different loads and slip ratios s, as shown in Table 2.

Question_4.Question: What was the main conclusion regarding the bearable load level of uncoated steel surfaces under dry lubrication?
Question_4.Source: The bearable load level of uncoated steel surfaces under dry lubrication is very low.

Question_5.Context: The study investigated the friction and temperature behavior of surface coatings in rolling-sliding contacts for dry lubricated gears. Question_5.Question: What was the main effect of surface coatings on the operating areas under dry lubrication?
Question_5.Source: Surface coatings can significantly increase operating areas under dry lubrication.

Question_6.Question: What was the main difference observed in the coefficients of friction between dry and oil injection lubrication?
Question_6.A: Higher coefficients of friction in dry lubrication
Question_6.B: Lower coefficients of friction in dry lubrication
Question_6.C: No difference in coefficients of friction
Question_6.D: Higher coefficients of friction in oil injection lubrication
Question_6.Source: Friction and bulk temperatures are considerably higher compared to oil lubrication.

Question_8.Context: The study focused on investigating the friction and temperature behavior of surface coatings in rolling-sliding contacts for dry lubricated gears. Question_8.Question: What was the main conclusion regarding the thermal performance of MoS2-BoC in terms of contact temperatures?
Question_8.Source: Contact temperatures under dry lubrication can be measured by thin-film sensors for bonded coatings if the electrical insulation is sufficient.

Question_9.Context: The study investigated the friction and temperature behavior of surface coatings in rolling-sliding contacts for dry lubricated gears. Question_9.Question: What was the main effect of low thermal effusivity of MoS2-BoC on contact temperatures?
Question_9.Source: Low thermal effusivity of bonded coatings can result in thermal insulation effects that can accelerate oxidation processes.
